Application_Facts: Applicant claimed 1,204 days of presence in Canada but had significant absences and insufficient documentation to verify addresses or family presence during the relevant period
Residency_Compliance: Failed to meet three-year physical presence requirement within four years prior to application
Procedural_Issue: Lack of corroborating documentation for residency claims
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Absence of supporting documents for claimed periods of residence
lack of verification for family presence in Canada
Credibility_Assessment: Insufficient evidence to establish factual basis for residency; credibility not explicitly challenged but burden of proof not met
Remedy_Sought: Reapplication after re-establishing residency
Legal_Standard_Applied: Koo qualitative test for residency
physical presence requirement
Decision_Rationale: Citizenship Judge reasonably concluded applicant did not meet residency requirements under subsection 5(1)(c); insufficient evidence to support claimed residency

Application_Facts: Appellant was physically present in Canada for only 232 days over a four-year period; maintained a home in Canada; paid taxes as a resident; promoted Canadian interests in Hong Kong; absences were due to business responsibilities in Hong Kong
Residency_Compliance: No, did not accumulate at least three years of residence in Canada within four years preceding application
Procedural_Issue: Appeal involved a trial de novo before the Federal Court
Evidence_Used: Physical presence records, ownership/maintenance of home in Canada, tax filings, promotion of Canadian interests, nature and purpose of absences
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient demonstration that connection to Canada was more substantial than to Hong Kong
Remedy_Sought: Overturn of citizenship judge's decision
Legal_Standard_Applied: Residence under Section 5(1)(c) requires both physical presence and intent to reside, with stronger ties to Canada than to another country
Decision_Rationale: Appellant's absences were not temporary; business responsibilities in Hong Kong outweighed his connections to Canada; residence requirement not satisfied despite some ties to Canada

Application_Facts: Applicant failed to accumulate at least 1,095 days of physical residence in Canada within a four-year period; errors in day count and misinterpretation of evidence regarding residency patterns
Residency_Compliance: Not met, as per initial decision; subject to reassessment due to errors
Procedural_Issue: Factual errors by Citizenship Judge, misapplication of the 'centralized mode of existence' test from Re Koo, failure to compare connections to Canada and other countries
Evidence_Used: Residency records, travel history, personal ties to Canada and other countries
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Incorrect calculation of residency days, incomplete analysis of comparative ties to other countries
Outcome: Case remanded for redetermination by another Citizenship Judge
Remedy_Sought: Reassessment of residency compliance under correct legal framework
Legal_Standard_Applied: Centralized mode of existence test (from Re Koo)
Decision_Rationale: Significant factual and legal errors undermined the original decision; need for proper application of residency test and accurate factual findings
Authority_Responsible: Citizenship Commission (on appeal), to be reassessed by a new Citizenship Judge

Application_Facts: Dr. El Ocla was absent from Canada due to professional obligations but maintained strong ties to Canada, including centralized mode of living in Canada
Residency_Compliance: Physical presence not met (1095 days in 4 years), but qualitative residency potentially satisfied
Procedural_Issue: Citizenship judge failed to consider qualitative residency test under s 5(1)(c)
Evidence_Used: Evidence of professional absences, maintained ties to Canada
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Judge did not assess evidence relevant to qualitative residency
Decision_Outcome: Original application rejected based solely on physical presence
Remedy_Sought: Reassessment by another citizenship judge applying both physical and qualitative tests
Legal_Standard_Applied: Physical presence test under Citizenship Act; failure to apply qualitative residency test under s 5(1)(c)
Decision_Rationale: The citizenship judge erred by not considering the qualitative residency test despite evidence of centralized life in Canada

Application_Facts: Appellant accumulated only 357 days of residence within the four years preceding the application; time spent studying abroad did not count toward residency
Procedural_Issue: Appeal from citizenship judge's decision
Evidence_Used: Record of days physically present in Canada
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient proof of required 1,095 days of residency
Remedy_Sought: Reapplication after fulfilling residency requirement
Legal_Standard_Applied: Statutory interpretation of s. 5(1)(c) of the Citizenship Act
Decision_Rationale: The residency requirement ensures 'Canadianization'; absence from Canada for extended periods, including for study, does not fulfill the statutory obligation

Application_Facts: Applicant was physically present for 621 days out of the required 1095 days in the four years preceding application.
Absence due to spousal support during husband's temporary work assignment abroad.
Prior to absence, applicant lived and worked in Canada, paid taxes, and established a home.
Residency_Compliance: Insufficient physical presence but maintained strong ties to Canada
Procedural_Issue: Appeal to Federal Court - Trial Division following denial by Citizenship judge
Evidence_Used: Duration of physical presence in Canada
Proof of home establishment in Canada
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Citizenship judge failed to properly consider temporary nature of absence and ties to Canada
Remedy_Sought: Overturning of Citizenship judge's decision
Legal_Standard_Applied: Three-year residency requirement under paragraph 5(1)(c) of the Citizenship Act with allowance for temporary absences
Decision_Rationale: Absence was temporary and justified by spousal support.
Applicant maintained significant ties to Canada.
Citizenship judge erred in failing to properly assess the temporary nature of the absence and the strength of the applicant's connections to Canada.
Authority_Responsible: Citizenship judge, Federal Court - Trial Division

Application_Facts: Applicants had significant absences from Canada; incomplete documentation including tax returns, health records, and bank statements with gaps
Residency_Compliance: Failed to accumulate at least 1,095 days of residence in Canada within the 1,460 days preceding application
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review process initiated under Federal Courts Act
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Incomplete documentation; gaps in records proving physical presence in Canada
Credibility_Assessment: Not explicitly challenged; deficiency in evidence rather than credibility found
Remedy_Sought: Granting of Canadian citizenship or remittal for reconsideration
Legal_Standard_Applied: Residency requirement under paragraph 5(1)(c) of the Citizenship Act
Decision_Rationale: The citizenship judge reasonably concluded that the applicants did not meet the required residency threshold due to insufficient proof

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether failure to disclose change in marital status constitutes misrepresentation under s. 27(1)(e)
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's claim of ignorance rejected
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Signed immigration documents declaring accuracy of information
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Failure to update marital status before entry
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Duty to disclose material facts regardless of intent
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Misrepresentation includes non-disclosure of material facts
Crimes.Document_Fraud: False declaration through omission in official forms

Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant married before landing but did not report it
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Applicant seeking entry as single individual
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Failed to comply with disclosure requirements
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of proof of notification of marital change
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Ignorance not accepted as defense
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Failure to disclose material fact constitutes misrepresentation regardless of intent

Application_Facts: Applicant was physically present in Canada for only 173 days, falling short of the required 1,095 days; lived and worked in Mexico
Procedural_Issue: Appeal filed under subsection 14(5) of the Citizenship Act
Evidence_Used: Record of physical presence in Canada
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient days of physical presence documented
Remedy_Sought: Overturn Citizenship Judge's decision
Legal_Standard_Applied: 1,095 days of physical presence in Canada as established in Re Pourghasemi
Decision_Rationale: Citizenship Judge correctly applied the residency requirement and provided adequate reasons; applicant failed to meet physical presence requirement

Crimes.Crime_Name: Inadmissibility due to health under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: s. 38(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA)
Crimes.Application_Facts: Rashid is HIV-positive and asymptomatic; submitted financial support documents and medical reports; medication costs exceed health cost threshold
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Not applicable – application for entry denied
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Whether the visa officer fulfilled duty to consider private financial support
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court's jurisdiction to review administrative decision on reasonableness
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Excessive demand on health services as defined under IRPA
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Medication costs exceed provincial health cost threshold; financial support does not negate excessive demand
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Visa Officer, supported by Medical Officer

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether visa officer’s reliance on medical assessment constitutes reasonable finding of excessive demand
Crimes.Governing_Law: s. 38(1)(c) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Court assessed medical cost projections and applicant's financial capacity
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate no excessive demand
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Rashid’s ability to pay medication costs privately was considered but not determinative
Crimes.Legal_Rule: A health condition may lead to inadmissibility if it causes excessive demand on health services
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged failure to consider private payment capacity
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, administrative law principles
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Visa officer maintained decision based on statutory criteria
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Certification of question and overturning of decision

Application_Facts: Applicant provided evidence of 1178 days of physical presence in Canada
Residency_Compliance: Met quantitative requirement (1178 days), but qualitative test improperly applied
Procedural_Issue: Improper application of qualitative test despite meeting quantitative threshold
Evidence_Used: Documentation proving 1178 days of physical presence
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Citizenship Judge ignored reliable evidence of physical presence
Decision_Outcome: Citizenship application denied by Citizenship Judge
Remedy_Sought: Redetermination of application by another Citizenship Judge
Legal_Standard_Applied: Qualitative test from Koo case
Decision_Rationale: Judge erred by applying qualitative test when quantitative requirement was met; reliable evidence of physical presence was disregarded

Legal_Provision_Violated: Section C.08.002 of the Food and Drug Regulations
Application_Facts: Applicant submitted a New Drug Submission (NDS) without clinical trial data; Health Canada rejected it for insufficient information on safety and effectiveness.
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review application challenging administrative decision
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of clinical trial data to support safety and efficacy claims
Decision_Outcome: Health Canada's rejection of NDS upheld
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed with costs to respondents
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of Health Canada's decision
Remedy_Sought: Overturning of Health Canada's decision
Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness standard
Decision_Rationale: Health Canada's interpretation of Section C.08.002 as requiring clinical trial data is reasonable and within acceptable range of interpretations.

Application_Facts: Respondents knew of applicant's criminal charges since March 2011 but failed to inform counsel until October 2011; delay attributed to 'inadvertent oversight'
Misrepresentation_Element: Failure to timely disclose known criminal charges
Procedural_Issue: Motion for extension of time to file further affidavits
Evidence_Used: Knowledge of criminal charges from March 2011
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of reasonable explanation for delay in filing
Credibility_Assessment: Arguments of clean hands, futility, and credibility deemed inadequate by court
Outcome: No extension granted, costs not awarded
Relief_Sought: Extension of time to file further affidavits
Remedy_Sought: Permission to submit additional affidavits regarding new criminal charges
Legal_Standard_Applied: Rule 8: Continuing intention, merit, no prejudice, reasonable explanation for delay
Decision_Rationale: Delay due to 'inadvertent oversight' found insufficient; no reasonable explanation provided; negotiations over detention did not justify late disclosure

Crimes.Crime_Name: Submitting Counterfeit Documents under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the IAD erred in finding Kobrosli inadmissible for misrepresentation under s. 40(1)(a) IRPA
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), s. 40(1)(a)
Crimes.Outcome: Federal Court dismissed judicial review; removal order upheld
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Kobrosli's submission of a counterfeit document undermined credibility
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Counterfeit document submitted with study permit application
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Submission of a forged document that could induce error in immigration administration
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Potential for the misrepresentation to induce an error, regardless of withdrawal
Crimes.Decision_Maker: Immigration Appeal Division (IAD), reviewed by Federal Court
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Misrepresentation under s. 40(1)(a) IRPA requires material falsehood that could induce error
Crimes.Application_Factor: Withdrawal of application after submission of counterfeit document

Crimes.Application_Facts: Kobrosli submitted a false document to renew his study permit and later withdrew the application
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Foreign national applying for study permit renewal
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Submission of a counterfeit document containing false information
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Minister appealed ID’s initial finding of no inadmissibility to IAD
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: IAD had authority to reassess inadmissibility
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Counterfeit document and context of submission
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: None found by IAD or Federal Court
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Adverse inference drawn from submission of fraudulent document
Crimes.Outcome: Federal Court dismissed judicial review application
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Misrepresentation risked incorrect administration of the Act, even if application was withdrawn

Legal_Provision_Violated: Section of the Citizenship Act requiring 1095 days of physical presence in Canada over four years
Application_Facts: Applicants had discrepancies exceeding 400 days in ICES reports; strong ties to Canada but failed to meet statutory residency threshold
Residency_Compliance: Failed to meet 1095-day physical presence requirement
Procedural_Issue: Alleged breach of procedural fairness due to reliance on undisclosed ICES reports and application of Pourghasemi test instead of Koo test
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Applicants not given opportunity to address discrepancies in ICES reports
Outcome: Judge's decision upheld on judicial review
Remedy_Sought: Overturning of refusal and grant of citizenship
Legal_Standard_Applied: Pourghasemi test for residency calculation
Decision_Rationale: Residency requirement not met under any interpretation; use of Pourghasemi test was reasonable; no procedural unfairness as applicants were aware of residency issues

Application_Facts: Applicant was absent for 551 days, retained business ties in Colombia, and traveled frequently
Residency_Compliance: Failed to meet 1095-day physical presence requirement over 4 years
Evidence_Used: Record of absences (551 days), business ties in Colombia, travel history, Koo factors assessment
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient demonstration of primary connection to Canada
Credibility_Assessment: Absences viewed as a life pattern, not temporary; weak Canadian connections
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of citizenship judge's decision
Legal_Standard_Applied: Koo factors for assessing residency intent
Decision_Rationale: Judge reasonably concluded applicant did not meet residency requirement based on duration and pattern of absences and lack of strong ties to Canada

Violation_Type: Failure to adequately assess state protection
Legal_Provision_Violated: Convention Refugee Determination Division assessment standards
Application_Facts: Applicants faced threats, violence, and property damage due to religious conversion; reported incidents to police with no action taken
Claimant_Status: Applicants claiming refugee status based on religious persecution
Procedural_Issue: CRDD dismissed claim citing insufficient evidence without sufficient analysis of police inaction
Evidence_Used: Reports of threats, violence, property damage, and lack of police response
Evidentiary_Deficiency: CRDD found insufficient evidence of state protection failure; court found analysis inadequate
Outcome: Federal Court allowed application, set aside CRDD decision
Relief_Sought: Recognition as convention refugees, protection from return to Russia
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review, reevaluation by new CRDD panel
Legal_Standard_Applied: Well-founded fear of persecution, inability to avail of state protection
Decision_Rationale: CRDD's analysis of state protection was insufficient; remanded for reconsideration
Authority_Responsible: Convention Refugee Determination Division (CRDD), Federal Court

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to comply with residency requirements under the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Governing_Law: Citizenship Act, Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA)
Crimes.Application_Facts: Respondents provided evidence of physical presence exceeding 1,095 days in Canada over four years preceding application
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Met – more than 1,095 days of physical presence established
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Not found – no allegation of false documentation or intent to deceive
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Minister appealed Citizenship Judge’s decision without challenging credibility
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court had jurisdiction to review administrative decision
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Passive indicia and applicant testimony supporting physical presence
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Alleged by Minister but not substantiated on review
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Citizenship Judge found respondents credible; Minister did not challenge this
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Minister sought cancellation of citizenship approval
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Judge’s conclusion was transparent, justified, and based on sufficient evidence
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Citizenship Judge, reviewed by Federal Court

Crimes.Crime_Name: Inadmissibility under section 44 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Violation_Type: Potential inadmissibility due to failure to meet residency obligations
Crimes.Application_Facts: Respondents demonstrated over 1,095 days of physical presence in Canada
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Not present – no finding of intentional deception
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Minister failed to identify palpable and overriding error
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court properly exercised appellate jurisdiction
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Testimony supported by passive indicia of presence
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Claimed by Minister but not proven
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Respondents deemed credible by Citizenship Judge
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Minister sought removal or denial based on alleged non-compliance
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Decision was reasonable, transparent, and consistent with law and evidence
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Citizenship Judge, subject to Federal Court review

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Alleged insufficient proof of residency for citizenship
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of Citizenship Judge’s determination on residency compliance
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicants found credible; no adverse findings
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Documentary and testimonial evidence of physical presence
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Minister’s assertion of inadequate evidence of residency
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Credibility of applicants and supporting passive indicia
Crimes.Decision_Maker: Citizenship Judge, reviewed by Federal Court
Crimes.Application_Error: None identified – application process followed correctly
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Residency requirement of 1,095 days within four years
Crimes.Application_Factor: Length and quality of physical presence in Canada
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Not found – no evidence of forged or falsified documents

Application_Facts: Applicant claimed persecution in Croatia due to Serbian origin and in Serbia by her father
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review of RPD decision
Evidence_Used: Evidence presented before the RPD regarding persecution claims
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of credible evidence to support ongoing threat
Credibility_Assessment: RPD found no credible threat in either country based on evidence and time elapsed
Decision_Outcome: RPD rejected the applicant's refugee claim
Relief_Sought: Recognition as a refugee and protection under IRPA
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of RPD decision
Legal_Standard_Applied: Well-founded fear of persecution under IRPA
Decision_Rationale: RPD's decision was reasonable and adequately considered all evidence

Legal_Provision_Violated: Statutory limits on visa officer decision-making authority
Governing_Law: Immigration Act, applicable statutory framework governing visa officers' powers
Application_Facts: Visa officer initially refused application on January 10, 1994; issued a new refusal letter on March 16, 1994, with new grounds after applicant's challenge
Misrepresentation_Element: Alleged misrepresentation of qualifications and experience in the initial application
Procedural_Issue: Issuance of a second refusal decision without statutory authority to reconsider
Jurisdictional_Issue: Visa officer lacked jurisdiction to reconsider and issue a new refusal decision after the initial refusal
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of statutory basis for reinitiating decision-making process
Credibility_Assessment: Not explicitly addressed; focus was on procedural legality
Outcome: Judicial review application dismissed; applicant may seek extension to challenge original January 10, 1994, decision
Relief_Sought: Invalidation of the March 16, 1994, refusal decision
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of the visa officer's decision
Legal_Standard_Applied: Statutory interpretation of visa officer's decision-making powers
Standard_of_Review: Correctness, as it involves a question of jurisdiction and statutory authority
Decision_Rationale: Once a visa officer exercises statutory authority to refuse an application, they cannot issue a new refusal unless statute permits reconsideration. The officer had no such authority here.

Application_Facts: Mr. Huang claimed fear of persecution due to membership in an underground Christian church; he had limited education and exposure to Christianity
Procedural_Issue: RPD applied an unrealistically high standard by focusing on minor doctrinal errors
Evidence_Used: Mr. Huang's testimony, knowledge of Christian beliefs
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Limited Christian doctrinal knowledge attributed to lack of education and exposure
Credibility_Assessment: RPD doubted Mr. Huang's credibility based on limited Christian knowledge
Decision_Outcome: RPD denied refugee status based on lack of credibility
Outcome: Judicial review found the RPD's decision unreasonable; decision vacated
Relief_Sought: Recognition as a refugee, protection from removal to China
Remedy_Sought: Reassessment of refugee claim by a new RPD panel
Legal_Standard_Applied: Well-founded fear of persecution under IRPA
Decision_Rationale: RPD's focus on minor doctrinal inconsistencies was unreasonable given Mr. Huang's background; overall circumstances and genuine belief were not adequately considered
Authority_Responsible: Immigration and Refugee Board (IRB), Refugee Protection Division (RPD)

Application_Facts: Applicant failed to provide admissible evidence proving his identity as Somali; submitted affidavits, declarations, and a linguistic report deemed inadmissible
Procedural_Issue: Allegation of violation of procedural fairness in the assessment of evidence by PRRA Officer
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Evidence lacked probative value and was not reasonably available or newly arising post-refugee claim rejection
Credibility_Assessment: PRRA Officer found submitted evidence insufficient to establish identity or risk
Decision_Outcome: PRRA application rejected due to inadmissible and non-probative evidence
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of PRRA Officer's decision
Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness under IRPA Section 113(a)
Decision_Rationale: PRRA Officer's decision was reasonable and consistent with prior RPD findings; no new or admissible evidence presented

Violation_Type: Failure to meet physical presence requirement
Application_Facts: Applicant was absent from Canada for 200 days due to caring for her ill mother and business trips
Residency_Compliance: Failed to accumulate 1095 days of residence in Canada over four years
Procedural_Issue: Appeal to the Federal Court after denial by Citizenship Judge
Evidence_Used: Records of absences, humanitarian reasons for travel
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of sufficient evidence to meet physical presence test despite compelling reasons
Remedy_Sought: Reapplication after meeting residency requirements
Legal_Standard_Applied: 1095-day physical presence requirement under paragraph 5(1)(c) of the Citizenship Act
Decision_Rationale: The Citizenship Judge reasonably applied the physical presence test within their discretion; humanitarian reasons did not override statutory requirement

Application_Facts: Discrepancies in the applicant's testimony were attributed to translation problems between Yoruba and Igbo interpreters.
Procedural_Issue: RPD failed to consider translation issues when assessing credibility.
Evidence_Used: Testimony of the applicant, interpreter services (Yoruba and Igbo)
Evidentiary_Deficiency: RPD did not address potential translation errors despite explanations from the applicant.
Credibility_Assessment: RPD found applicant not credible due to contradictions without considering translation issues; assessment deemed unreasonable.
Outcome: Remanded for reconsideration by a differently constituted RPD
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review, reconsideration of credibility
Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness standard
Decision_Rationale: Failure to consider translation issues rendered credibility assessment unreasonable.

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Failure to disclose prior refusals and procedural fairness
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act and Regulations
Crimes.Outcome: Decision set aside, case returned for reconsideration
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant provided explanations later; officer did not adequately assess
Crimes.Legal_Provision: IRPA and IRPR - requirement to declare prior refusals
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of adequate response to applicant's explanation by officer
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to initially declare prior refusal
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Procedural fairness and truthfulness in application
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Duty of procedural fairness under administrative law
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Unreasonable decision due to procedural unfairness
Crimes.Document_Fraud: No explicit fraud found, but omission initially made

Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act - duration of stay
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Failed to comply with authorized stay period
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Officer failed to consider detailed explanation for overstay
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Assessment of intent and ties to home country
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Explanation letters, evidence of ties to Japan
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Officer misinterpreted facts about ties to Japan
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant provided credible reasons for overstay
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Decision found unreasonable and set aside
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Judicial review of work permit refusal
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Officer failed to engage with explanation and applied incorrect reasoning
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Visa officer at Canadian visa office

Crimes.Crime_Name: Work Permit Refusal under Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of work permit refusal
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Refusal based on failure to declare refusals, overstay, and lack of new employment contract
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act and Regulations
Crimes.Outcome: Decision set aside, remitted for reconsideration
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant provided explanations; officer failed to address them
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Labour Market Opinion, explanation for overstay, employment history
Crimes.Legal_Provision: IRPR sections related to work permit eligibility
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Alleged non-compliance with work permit requirements
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Officer ignored valid LMO and applicant’s explanations
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to declare prior refusal, lack of new contract
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Compliance with IRPR and procedural fairness
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Valid Labour Market Opinion, explanation for overstay
Crimes.Application_Factor: Intent to leave Canada, job offer validity
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Unreasonable decision due to flawed reasoning
Crimes.Document_Fraud: No document forgery, but concerns about completeness of disclosure

Legal_Issue: Whether the Officer's refusal of the Applicants' humanitarian and compassionate (H&C) application was justified under section 25 of IRPA
Outcome: The application for judicial review is dismissed
Evidence_Type: Integration, employment, community involvement, children’s circumstances
Basis_of_Claim: Humanitarian and compassionate grounds to avoid unusual, undeserved, or disproportionate hardship
Key_Factor_in_Determination: No exceptional hardship found; best interests of children considered
Legal_Standard: Reasonableness, transparency, and legal discretion under IRPA
Application_Factor: Family establishment in Canada, integration into society

Application_Facts: Applicants overstayed visas, integrated into Canadian society, have two children
Procedural_Issue: Adequacy of reasons, proper test application, evidence consideration
Evidence_Used: Integration, family ties, potential hardships to children
Decision_Outcome: Refusal of humanitarian and compassionate application
Relief_Sought: Permanent residency on humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of refusal decision
Legal_Standard_Applied: Unusual, undeserved, or disproportionate hardship under s. 25 IRPA
Decision_Rationale: No unusual hardship established despite family ties and integration

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refugee claim based on fear of imprisonment
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether imprisonment for overstaying a Cuban exit visa constitutes persecution or cruel and unusual punishment
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) sections 96 and 97
Crimes.Outcome: Risk of imprisonment does not amount to persecution or cruel treatment
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Evidence of imprisonment risk was speculative
Crimes.Legal_Provision: IRPA s. 96 (refugee protection), s. 97 (risk of cruel and unusual treatment)
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Fear of persecution due to visa overstay and family mistreatment
Crimes.Proceeding_Type: Judicial review of Immigration and Refugee Board decision
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to renew valid exit visa despite possibility
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness and correctness standards in judicial review
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Persecution requires more than self-created legal consequences

Crimes.Violation_Type: Failure to comply with exit visa conditions
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Cuban immigration regulations on exit visas
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant overstayed Cuban exit visa and did not renew it
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Applicant seeking refugee status in Canada
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Non-compliance with home country’s exit visa requirements
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of concrete evidence supporting imprisonment risk
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Claims deemed speculative and unsupported
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Protection from alleged persecution in Cuba
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Persecution must not arise from self-induced legal violations
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Self-created legal issues do not qualify as persecution
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Immigration and Refugee Board of Canada

Legal_Issue: Whether 'Glen Breton' is deceptively misdescriptive under the Trade-marks Act
Evidence_Assessment: No Canadian whisky with 'Glen' in name before 2000; 'Glen' associated with Scottish whisky; consumer confusion evidence introduced on appeal
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate registrability; opponent showed likelihood of confusion
Credibility_Factor: New evidence of consumer confusion admitted on appeal
Legal_Rule: Marks that are deceptively misdescriptive or have recognized geographic association are not registrable
Grounds_for_Claim: 'Glen Breton' falsely suggests Scotch origin due to use of 'Glen'
Key_Evidence_Considered: Commercial usage of 'Glen' in whisky branding; absence of prior Canadian use; consumer perception data
Defendant_Response: Glenora Distillers defended trademark application as distinctive and not misleading
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence, commercial usage records, consumer survey data (implied)
Remedy_Requested: Refusal of trademark registration by Scotch Whisky Association

Outcome: Court allowed judicial review, set aside decision, remanded for redetermination
Credibility_Assessment: Assumption made about applicant's intent to return without opportunity to respond
Evidence_Type: Applicant's ties to Colombia, study history in Canada
Basis_of_Claim: Assumed lack of intent to leave Canada after studies
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of opportunity to address concerns about intent to return
Application_Error: Failure to provide applicant chance to clarify intent
Evidence_Ignored: Potential evidence of ties to Colombia
Legal_Standard: Natural justice, fairness in administrative decision-making
Application_Factor: Duration of study in Canada affecting perceived ties to home country
Decision_Outcome: Denial of study permit and temporary resident visa

Crimes.Crime_Name: Kidnapping and/or extortion in urban and rural locations, especially in Caracas
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Board erred in concluding no risk of persecution and a viable internal flight alternative (IFA) existed
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Board ignored evidence of ongoing threats to applicant's family and widespread kidnapping/extortion reports
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Application for judicial review allowed; Board’s decision set aside and remitted for re-determination

Crimes.Evidence_Sufficiency: Corroborative evidence from family about ongoing threats was present but ignored
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Board failed to properly assess credibility despite supporting evidence
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Refugee Protection Division guidelines on persecution risk and IFA

Crimes.Evidence_Sufficiency: Documentary evidence of ongoing threats was provided
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Board failed to address key evidence
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Refugee law standards for well-founded fear and internal flight alternative

Crimes.Risk_Assessment: High risk due to ongoing threats and targeting
Crimes.Risk_Type: Persecution based on membership in a particular social group
Crimes.Evidence_Sufficiency: Sufficient evidence of extortion and continued danger
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Affidavits, family testimony, country condition reports
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Board dismissed claim without proper analysis
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), s. 96 and 97

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Lack of nexus to Convention grounds, state protection, internal flight alternative
Crimes.Outcome: Board's decision quashed, case remanded for reconsideration
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant provided credible evidence of threats from corrupt police
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Fear of persecution due to refusal to participate in illegal activities and reporting corruption
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Immediate threat from state actors, lack of effective state protection
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to properly assess nexus, state protection, and internal flight alternative
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Credible evidence of immediate danger and institutional failure
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Well-founded fear of persecution on Convention grounds

Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Abuse of official power, ongoing threats
Crimes.Prior_Criminality: Pattern of corruption and intimidation by police
Crimes.Criminality_Severity: High – credible threat of bodily harm
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: High risk of harm if returned
Crimes.Targeted_Individual: Applicant who refused to transport drugs and reported corruption
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant found credible by Court

Crimes.Victim_Status: Whistleblower targeted for resistance to criminal activity
Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Use of official position to commit violence
Crimes.Prior_Criminality: History of police corruption and abuse
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: High risk of re-assault upon return
Crimes.Targeted_Individual: Applicant who resisted drug trafficking involvement
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Consistent and plausible account

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Availability of state protection and internal flight alternative
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Board failed to consider credible evidence
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to show lack of state protection
Crimes.Legal_Rule: State protection must be effective and accessible
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Persecution due to political opinion and reporting corruption
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Threats from police, denial of protection
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Board claimed other agencies could protect applicant
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Quashing of decision and referral back

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Nexus to Convention grounds, state protection, internal flight alternative
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: Applicant must demonstrate inability to access protection
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Well-founded fear based on political opinion or protected ground
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Refusal to engage in bribery and reporting corruption
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Threats after refusing bribe and reporting misconduct
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Board asserted availability of protection elsewhere in Mexico

Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Crimes.Victim_Basis: Moral opposition to criminal conduct within state institutions

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Linkage to Convention grounds, adequacy of state protection, internal flight alternative
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to prove lack of viable alternatives
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Persecution based on political opinion includes anti-corruption stance
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Refusal to comply with illegal demands by officials
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Direct threats following report of misconduct

Application_Facts: Applicant claims she will face persecution from former traffickers if returned to Romania due to inadequate state protection.
Procedural_Issue: PRRA Officer erred by relying on Romania's efforts rather than its effectiveness.
Evidence_Used: Evidence shows corruption, recapture risks, and insufficient police capability.
Evidentiary_Deficiency: PRRA Officer relied on insufficient evidence of effective state protection.
Decision_Outcome: Removal order stayed until judicial review application is resolved.
Outcome: Stay of removal granted pending judicial review.
Remedy_Sought: Protection from deportation due to risk of harm
Legal_Standard_Applied: State protection requires both the will and capacity of the government to effectively implement legislation and programs to protect victims.
Standard_of_Review: Tripartite test: serious issue, irreparable harm, balance of convenience
Decision_Rationale: Applicant has raised a serious issue, faces irreparable harm, and the balance of convenience favors granting a stay of removal.

Criminality_Severity: High – risk of retribution and sexual exploitation
Risk_Nature: Targeted harm by non-state actors due to prior exploitation
Evidence_Credibility: Credible based on consistency and corroboration

Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Dispute_Type: Inadequate state protection for trafficking victims
Legal_Provision_Involved: Section 97(1) IRPA – Danger to life, liberty, or cruel treatment
Grounds_for_Claim: Risk of persecution due to ineffective state protection
Legal_Framework: International human rights law, domestic refugee protection framework
Decision_Outcome: Removal order stayed pending judicial review
Targeted_Group: Trafficking survivors returning to home country
State_Protection_Assessment: Romanian state lacks capacity due to corruption and weak enforcement
Legal_Provision: IRPA, Charter of Rights and Freedoms
State_Protection_Adequacy: Inadequate – lack of will and capacity
Risk_Nature: Non-state actor violence with state complicity or neglect
Perpetrator_Entity: Human traffickers, potentially aided by corrupt officials

Violation_Type: Failure to properly assess state protection
Application_Facts: PRRA Officer ignored evidence of corruption and specific threats; focused on formal measures over actual protection
Procedural_Issue: Error in applying legal standard for state protection
Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court jurisdiction to review PRRA decisions
Evidence_Used: Evidence of police corruption, inadequate response, and personal threats
Evidentiary_Deficiency: PRRA Officer failed to consider key evidence on effectiveness of protection
Credibility_Assessment: Applicant’s claims treated as credible by the court
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of PRRA decision
Legal_Standard_Applied: Tripartite test for stay: serious issue, irreparable harm, balance of convenience
Decision_Rationale: Applicant demonstrated serious issue regarding state protection, risk of irreparable harm, and favorable balance of convenience

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to comply with immigration requirements
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the immigration officer erred in denying the H&C claim
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, Section 25
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Insufficient evidence of unusual or disproportionate hardship
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On the applicant to demonstrate humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Applicant had unauthorized stay and prior rejections
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Section 25 allows discretion to grant permanent residency on H&C grounds
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Claim denied due to lack of exceptional hardship
Key_Evidence_Considered: History of visa extensions and unauthorized stay
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Permanent residency based on H&C grounds

Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicants remained in Canada after visa expiry, refugee claims rejected
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Korean national with rejected refugee claim
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant – overstayed visa and unauthorized presence
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Not applicable – no finding of misrepresentation
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court jurisdiction under Section 72 of IRPA
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of proof of unusual or disproportionate hardship
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: History of non-compliance considered but not determinative
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Permanent residency on humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: No unusual or disproportionate hardship established

Crime_Name: Failure to Provide Adequate Reasons for Citizenship Decision
Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Grounds_for_Claim: Lack of written reasons despite approval of application not meeting residency requirements
Decision_Outcome: Case referred back for written reasons within 90 days
Credibility: Decision lacked explanation, raising concerns about procedural fairness
Legal_Provision: Subsection 14(5) of the Citizenship Act (basis for appeal)

Legal_Issue: Whether Exhibit 'A1' is protected by solicitor-client privilege and if inadvertent disclosure constitutes waiver
Governing_Law: Solicitor-client privilege principles under common law
Procedural_Stage: Appeal of Prothonotary's ruling under Federal Courts Rules
Evidence_Assessment: Exhibit 'A1' involves communication for legal advice; inadvertently disclosed but privilege asserted promptly
Burden_of_Proof: Defendants failed to prove waiver of privilege
Credibility_Factor: Plaintiffs immediately asserted privilege upon realization of disclosure
Legal_Rule: Solicitor-client privilege protects confidential communications for legal advice; inadvertent disclosure does not waive privilege without intent
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness or correctness, as applicable to Prothonotary's decision
Grounds_for_Claim: Defendants argued no privilege existed or was waived due to disclosure
Key_Evidence_Considered: Exhibit 'A1' – communication between client and lawyer seeking legal advice
Legal_Framework: Federal Courts Rules; common law on solicitor-client privilege
Remedy_Requested: Overturn privilege ruling and allow use of Exhibit 'A1'
Legal_Provision: Common law doctrine of solicitor-client privilege
Authority: Prothonotary Lafrenière; Federal Court appellate authority

Legal_Issue: Likelihood of confusion between POLYSORB and POLYSOFT trademarks for shoe insoles
Evidence_Assessment: Credibility issues with consumer confusion evidence
Decision_Outcome: Summary judgment dismissed; case proceeds to trial
Burden_of_Proof: Plaintiff must prove likelihood of confusion
Credibility_Factor: Need for viva voce testimony on confusion and passing-off claims
Legal_Rule: Confusion occurs when use of a trademark leads to inference that goods are from the same source
Standard_of_Review: Summary judgment standard requiring no genuine issue for trial
Grounds_for_Claim: Defendant's use of POLYSOFT for identical products with similar appearance/sound
Outcome_on_Merits: Not decided; genuine issue for trial
Key_Evidence_Considered: Similarity of marks, identity of goods, overlap in trade, consumer perception
Legal_Framework: Trade-marks Act, Canadian intellectual property law
Defendant_Response: Motion for summary judgment seeking dismissal
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence, allegations of consumer confusion
Outcome: Case proceeds to trial; plaintiff awarded costs
Authority: Court considering motion for summary judgment under applicable procedural rules

Legal_Issue: Was the visa officer's refusal to assess the applicant as a general economist an error in law?
Governing_Law: Under the Immigration Act and Regulations, visa officers must assess applicants based on their claimed occupation unless clearly unqualified.
Outcome: The visa officer erred in law by failing to assess the applicant in her claimed occupation of general economist.
Basis_of_Claim: The applicant was not assessed as a general economist despite claiming this occupation.
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Visa officer assessed applicant under incorrect occupations ('manager administration' and 'financial manager') not aligned with application.
Application_Error: Failure to assess applicant in claimed occupation of general economist
Assessment_Standard: Applicants must be assessed based on their claimed occupation unless clearly unqualified
Evidence_Ignored: Applicant's stated intended occupation as general economist
Legal_Standard: Error in law due to misapplication of assessment criteria under the Immigration Act and Regulations
Decision_Outcome: Case remanded for redetermination by a different visa officer

Dispute_Type: Classification of farming activities for tax deduction purposes
Legal_Issue: Whether the plaintiff was a 'class (I) farmer' entitled to deduct farming losses under s. 31 of the Income Tax Act
Governing_Law: Section 31 of the Income Tax Act
Evidence_Assessment: Plaintiff's time spent on farming, capital investment, borrowing, reduction in reliance on managerial job, impact of drought and economic conditions
Decision_Outcome: Judgment in favor of the plaintiff
Burden_of_Proof: Plaintiff demonstrated commitment to farming as chief source of income
Credibility_Factor: Plaintiff moved to farm, invested savings, worked long hours, borrowed heavily
Legal_Rule: A taxpayer is a 'class (I) farmer' if farming is their chief source of income or combined with another source, considering time, capital, and profitability
Standard_of_Review: Assessment of facts and application of statutory criteria
Grounds_for_Claim: Entitlement to deduct farming losses based on classification as class (I) farmer
Outcome_on_Merits: Plaintiff qualifies as a class (I) farmer
Key_Evidence_Considered: Investment of savings, loans taken, hours worked, shift from managerial work, agricultural challenges
Evidence_Type: Financial records, time allocation, loan documents, employment history
Remedy_Requested: Full deduction of farming losses for 1978–1980
Outcome: Allowed full deduction of farming losses

Legal_Issue: Whether the Refugee Protection Division's decision was based on unreasonable credibility assessments
Outcome: Judicial review granted, case referred back for redetermination
Credibility_Assessment: Found to be unreasonable; focused on peripheral inconsistencies
Legal_Provision: Subsection 72(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Basis_of_Claim: Persecution in Cameroon due to political activities
Application_Error: Failure to consider reasonable explanations for inconsistencies
Evidence_Ignored: Applicant's explanations for discrepancies such as prison name and signing documents without reading
Legal_Standard: Justification, transparency, and intelligibility in decision-making
Application_Factor: Inconsistencies in testimony deemed minor and peripheral
Decision_Outcome: Rejection of refugee claim set aside
Document_Fraud: Alleged signing of documents without reading, no finding of actual fraud

Crimes.Crime_Name: Misrepresentation under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the RAD properly applied a reasonableness standard to assess the RPD's credibility findings
Crimes.Outcome: Application for judicial review allowed; matter referred back to RAD for reconsideration
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: RPD and RAD found applicant not credible; credibility was central to the determination
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Testimonial evidence, documentary evidence related to persecution claims
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Persecution in India due to homosexuality
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to justify use of reasonableness standard in context of IRPA provisions
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness standard applied but deemed inappropriate without proper justification
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Potential lack of thorough analysis of credibility grounds and supporting evidence
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Reasonableness vs. correctness in administrative review
Crimes.Application_Factor: Nature of the legal issue and statutory context under IRPA

Crimes.Crime_Name: Use of False Documents for Immigration Purpose
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Immigration and refugee status appeal involving document authenticity
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the RAD properly applied the reasonableness standard to credibility findings in light of false documents
Crimes.Outcome: Application for judicial review allowed; matter referred back to RAD for reconsideration
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Credibility rejected by RPD due to use of false documents, upheld by RAD
Crimes.Evidence_Type: False identification or supporting documents submitted in refugee claim
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Persecution due to homosexuality in home country
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Use of false documents affecting credibility
Crimes.Application_Error: Inappropriate deference to RPD despite issues with document fraud
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness standard applied incorrectly without re-evaluating credibility de novo where required
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Potential failure to reassess credibility independently in presence of document fraud
Crimes.Application_Factor: Presence of fraudulent documentation impacting truthfulness

Crimes.Crime_Name: Submitting counterfeit documents for immigration purposes
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the IAD erred in finding Mr. Kobrosli inadmissible under paragraph 40(1)(a) of the IRPA due to misrepresentation
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), paragraph 40(1)(a)
Crimes.Outcome: IAD's decision upheld; Mr. Kobrosli found inadmissible
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Submission of a counterfeit document undermined credibility
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Submission of counterfeit document for student status renewal and QAC application
Crimes.Application_Error: Use of counterfeit document in immigration application
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness standard applied to IAD's decision
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: None noted – IAD considered all relevant evidence
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Misrepresentation under IRPA that could induce error in administration
Crimes.Application_Factor: Document submitted for study permit renewal and QAC application
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Judicial review dismissed; removal order issued

Crimes.Crime_Name: Misrepresentation under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Did the IAD err in finding Mr. Kobrosli inadmissible under paragraph 40(1)(a) of the IRPA for misrepresentation?
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), paragraph 40(1)(a)
Crimes.Outcome: Court dismissed judicial review; IAD decision upheld
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Submission of counterfeit document affected truthfulness
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Counterfeit document used in immigration applications
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Misrepresentation through submission of false documentation
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Potential to induce error in immigration administration
Crimes.Proceeding_Type: Judicial review of IAD decision reversing ID ruling
Crimes.Application_Error: Inclusion of fraudulent document in application
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Misrepresentation or withholding material facts under IRPA
Crimes.Application_Factor: Use of document for study permit and QAC application
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Mr. Kobrosli deemed inadmissible; removal order issued

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to disclose material facts under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Did the IAD err in finding Mr. Kobrosli inadmissible under paragraph 40(1)(a) of the IRPA?
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), paragraph 40(1)(a)
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review dismissed; IAD decision affirmed
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Act of submitting counterfeit document despite withdrawal indicates lack of candor
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Counterfeit document submitted for student status application
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Submission of false document and failure to correct record
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Potential for administrative error due to false information
Crimes.Proceeding_Type: Judicial review of IAD decision based on evidence and legal principles
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Misrepresentation or omission of material facts under IRPA
Crimes.Application_Factor: False document submitted for immigration benefits
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Mr. Kobrosli found inadmissible; removal order upheld
